description.narrative: Output 2016-2017: D'ici Ã fin 2017, au moins 100.000 nouvelles personnes dans les communautÃ©s, les Ã©coles, et les centres de santÃ© ont un accÃ¨s Ã un assainissement de base et pratiquent le lavage de mains.Output 2014-2015: By 31 December 2015, at least 54% of households in the Plateau Central, Centre Nord, Boucle du Mouhoun and Hauts Basins regions apply the basic rules of hygiene and have a permanent and equitable access to basic sanitationOutput 2011-2013: By the end of 2015, household members and students of the educational system in the Plateau Central and Centre Nord regions have permanent and equitable access to improved sanitation, with targets: 54 per cent for Ganzourgou and 30 per cent for KourwÃ©ogo and Oubritenga (provinces in Plateau Central region), 10 per cent for Bam (province in Centre Nord region)), which contributes to Hygiene, Sanitation, Wash And Emergencies, Wash In Schools And Ecd Centres, Wash â€“ General. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: D'ici fin 2017, l'UNICEF contribue Ã accroitre l'accÃ¨s Ã l'eau potable et Ã l'assainissement amÃ©liorÃ©e au milieu rural. By 2015, the percentage of the population using a safe water source for drinking water increases from 56 per cent to 76 per cent, and the percentage of households using improved sanitation facilities increases from 10 per cent to 54 per cent.

title.narrative: Output 2016-2017: D?ici a fin 2017, au moins 100.000 nouvelles personnes dans les communautes, les ecoles, et les centres de santeont un acces a un assainissement de base et pratiquent le lavage de mains.Output 2014-2015: By 31 December 2015, at least 54% ofhouseholds in the Plateau Central, Centre Nord, Boucle du Mouhoun and Hauts Basins regions apply the basic rules of hygiene andhave a permanent and equitable access to basic sanitationOutput 2011-2013: By the end of 2015, household members and students ofthe educational system in the Plateau Central and Centre Nord regions have permanent and equitable access to improved sanitation,with targets: 54 per cent for Ganzourgou and 30 per cent for Kourweogo and Oubritenga (provinces in Plateau Central region), 10 percent for Bam (province in Centre Nord region))

description.narrative: UNICEF&39;s work focused on the advocacy with the Government aiming at the formal recognition of Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) as a national strategy. Results from the CLTS pilot project were evaluated through a joint review. In 150 schools, 43.691 students obtained access to sanitation and menstrual hygiene management. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:31/12/2017
